articles.headline: Israel’s Right-Wing Government Has Jewish Democrats at a Loss
articles.snippet: American lawmakers defending Israel have often fallen back on what they call the countries’ shared democratic values. But defending the current far-right government is proving a lot harder.
articles.abstract: American lawmakers defending Israel have often fallen back on what they call the countries’ shared democratic values. But defending the current far-right government is proving a lot harder.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last month, as demonstrations across Israel convulsed politics in the Jewish state, Jewish Democrats in the House who have made up the bulwark of Israel’s support on their side of the aisle met privately with the country’s ambassador.

articles.headline: Battle Over Labor Secretary Nominee Reflects a Larger Fight for Biden
articles.snippet: Business groups are critical of the candidate, Julie Su, and key senators are wavering. The administration’s labor policies are central to the clash.
articles.abstract: Business groups are critical of the candidate, Julie Su, and key senators are wavering. The administration’s labor policies are central to the clash.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just over a year ago, the White House suffered an embarrassing defeat when three Democratic senators voted against advancing President Biden’s pick to run a key labor agency, dealing a blow to the administration’s pro-labor agenda.

articles.headline: Franchisers, Facing Challenges to Business Model, Punch Back
articles.snippet: Discontented franchisees have found allies among state legislators and federal regulators in pushing for new laws and rules, but change has been slow.
articles.abstract: Discontented franchisees have found allies among state legislators and federal regulators in pushing for new laws and rules, but change has been slow.
articles.lead_paragraph: When you visit a McDonald's, a Jiffy Lube or a Hilton Garden Inn, you may assume you’re visiting one business. More likely, you’re actually visiting two: the operator of that particular location, known as the franchisee, and the larger company that owns the intellectual property behind it, or the franchiser.

articles.headline: Fox Settlement Is a Victory for Dominion. But the Misinformation War Continues.
articles.snippet: False claims about election fraud remain a problem, spreading in various places online, voting and media experts said.
articles.abstract: False claims about election fraud remain a problem, spreading in various places online, voting and media experts said.
articles.lead_paragraph: There are 787 million reasons to consider Fox News’s settlement of the defamation lawsuit a stunning victory for Dominion Voting Systems. Whether the millions of dollars that Fox is paying to Dominion will put to rest false claims about the 2020 presidential election or help deter misinformation more broadly remains far less clear.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers, Tiffany Hsu and Stuart A. Thompson

articles.headline: In a Nation Armed to the Teeth, These Tiny Missteps Led to Tragedy
articles.snippet: A workman knocking on the wrong door. A cheerleader mistaking another car for her own. Small errors can have large consequences in a nation bristling with guns.
articles.abstract: A workman knocking on the wrong door. A cheerleader mistaking another car for her own. Small errors can have large consequences in a nation bristling with guns.
articles.lead_paragraph: The maintenance man in North Carolina had just arrived to fix damage from a leak. The teenager in Georgia was only looking for his girlfriend’s apartment. The cheerleader in Texas simply wanted to find her car in a dark parking lot after practice.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy, Glenn Thrush, Eliza Fawcett and Susan C. Beachy

articles.headline: How Hard Lines in Fox-Dominion Deal Talks Suddenly Softened
articles.snippet: The $787.5 million settlement, believed to be the largest in a defamation case, came together quickly.
articles.abstract: The $787.5 million settlement, believed to be the largest in a defamation case, came together quickly.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Tuesday morning, as the legal team for Dominion Voting Systems walked from their hotel to the courthouse where they were about to finish jury selection, one lawyer turned to another and asked in a low voice about a possible settlement, “Is there anything going on?”
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters, Jim Rutenberg and Katie Robertson

articles.headline: America’s Inflation Villain Gets a Makeover
articles.snippet: As the Fed fights inflation with a wary eye on the 1970s, some are arguing that Arthur Burns, the Fed chair at the time, gets too bad a rap.
articles.abstract: As the Fed fights inflation with a wary eye on the 1970s, some are arguing that Arthur Burns, the Fed chair at the time, gets too bad a rap.
articles.lead_paragraph: The years have not been kind to Arthur Burns, who led the Federal Reserve from 1970 to 1978 and is often remembered as perhaps the worst chair ever to head America’s central bank. His poor policy decisions, critics say, allowed inflation in the 1970s to jump out of control.

articles.headline: A Radical Experiment in Mental Health Care, Tested Over Centuries
articles.snippet: In the Belgian town of Geel, families have long taken in people with psychiatric conditions. Could this approach work elsewhere?
articles.abstract: In the Belgian town of Geel, families have long taken in people with psychiatric conditions. Could this approach work elsewhere?
articles.lead_paragraph: A painful loop has defined Iosif’s 53 years on earth: trauma, mental breakdown, psychiatric institutionalization.
articles.byline: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Koba Ryckewaert and Ilvy Njiokiktjien

articles.headline: The Debt Ceiling Debate Is About More Than Debt
articles.snippet: Republicans’ opening bid to avert economic catastrophe by raising the nation’s borrowing limit focuses more on energy policy than reducing debt.
articles.abstract: Republicans’ opening bid to avert economic catastrophe by raising the nation’s borrowing limit focuses more on energy policy than reducing debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker Kevin McCarthy of California has repeatedly said that he and his fellow House Republicans are refusing to raise the nation’s borrowing limit, and risking economic catastrophe, to force a reckoning on America’s $31 trillion national debt.
